request_pathways.name: HCA Authorization for Release of PHI (English)
HCA Authorization for Release of PHI (Spanish)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads and fills the standard HCA authorization form, which serves both self-access and third-party release, then submits via fax, mail, or the Swellbox online portal.

bright_spots: Bilingual fillable PDFs (English and Spanish) with 52 interactive fields each
USCDI Release Request option for structured health data interoperability
Four delivery format options including encrypted email
Swellbox online portal and MyHealthONE patient portal as alternative digital pathways

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — web search immediately surfaced the well-organized medical records page with direct PDF download links for both languages.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital — the PDF has 52 fillable fields for complete digital form completion, but the PDF pathway requires fax or mail for submission; the Swellbox portal offers a fully digital alternative.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with three labeled sections, 16+ record-type checkboxes, and four delivery options, but the single-page density and some legal language (e.g., unencrypted email disclaimer) prevent a top score.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form serves both self-access and third-party release with no differentiation, and Section B (marketing/sale of PHI) adds irrelevant complexity for patients requesting their own records.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing material — no notarization, SSN optional, psychotherapy notes properly handled, appropriate patient rights statements, but fee language is vague ('reasonable copy fee' with no specifics) and fax is restricted to physician offices/medical facilities.

overall.summary: Strong technical form quality with fillable bilingual PDFs and multiple pathways, but the generic authorization design fails to differentiate patient self-access from third-party release.
